author: Alanna Bennett
title: That "Jane The Virgin" Death Could Serve As A New Beginning For The Show
text:
View this image ›
The CW ID: 10484549 2. It left a lot of fans reeling — and with a lot of questions. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10484606 3. After the episode aired, Jane the Virgin creator Jennie Snyder Urman took to Tumblr with an open letter to fans explaining the thought process behind the decision. View this image ›
Frederick M. Brown / Getty Images ID: 10484628 4. As she notes, the death was planned from the beginning — and the writers planted that infamous line about Michael loving Jane until his dying breath as a way of making themselves stick to the plan. Honestly, I put that line into the script at the last minute to hold our feet to the fire, to make sure we went through with it. Because even back then, the writers could all see the magic of Jane and Michael together. Not to mention Rogelio and Michael!
ID: 10484651 5. In fact, they loved Brett Dier (who plays Michael) so much that they let the character live longer than they were planning — so that he and Jane could have at least a little bit of the life they’d dreamed of together. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10484659 6. “But this is a telenovela, as we so frequently remind you,” Snyder Urman wrote. “And we are only at our midpoint.” View this image ›
Michael Desmond / Michael Desmond/The CW And so, Michael Cordero had to die — from a medical complication of when he was shot at the end of the second season.
ID: 10484716 7. The writers dropped hints throughout the series in an effort to both tease his death and potentially soften the blow. The narrator often foreshadowed that, for Jane and Michael, a happy ending wasn’t in the cards. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10485102 8. But his death begs the question: What comes next? As was revealed at the very end of the episode, Michael’s death comes with a three-year time jump. View this image ›
The CW / Via janevillanueva.tumblr.com ID: 10484662 9. This allows the writers to move forward with the story while using the show’s usual flashback elements to still flesh out Jane’s grief of Michael’s death. You’ll recall, back in the pilot, Jane was on a path. Things were mapped out. And then she was accidentally artificially inseminated and everything changed. Well now, everything is changing again. How does our romance-loving hero move on, how does she get back the light and the hope…?
Well, it’s certainly not quick. And that’s why we’re now three years later in our story. We’ll be flashing back to those three years and filling in gaps, but mining emotions realistically is something we work hard on and we knew the immediate pain of that loss would overwhelm our storytelling. After talking to grief counselors, this felt like the right time to reenter Jane’s journey. She’ll always feel Michael’s absence (and trust me, we will too), but it opens up our storytelling in new and exciting ways, while allowing for the light and bright Jane world that we love to write .
ID: 10484680 10. So yes, Jane the Virgin made a big sacrifice with that episode. But it was one they were always planning to make — and one that frees the writers to shake things up for virtually everyone. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10484952 11. For example: If they want to, they can jump straight past the storyline where Anezka and Scott were blackmailing Petra and Rafael over Emilo’s will. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10484969 12. They can send Rafael to prison without having to worry about taking his character out of the action — because they can skip right past the jail time and revisit him when he’s out as a (potentially) changed man, one he’s talked about wanting to be. View this image ›
The CW / Via giphy.com ID: 10484970 13. They can explore Jane’s grief in flashbacks, without it obscuring absolutely everything else. Now they can show what life is like for her down the line — when she still misses Michael, but can imagine an existence without him. Some things require time. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10484986 14. It could also allow them to explore new story opportunities for the children on the show. Mateo is now more of a kid than a toddler, and the twins may get more to do than sit in a crib. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10485029 15. Oh, and don’t forget: We’re getting a wedding. And it could be anyone’s. Xo’s to Bruce? Xo’s to Rogelio? Rogelio to Darci? Petra’s to therapy? WHO KNOWS. View this image ›
The CW ID: 10485046 16. So the story of Michael’s life may end here — but Jane the Virgin certainly doesn’t. In fact, as Snyder Urman, said, we’re only halfway done. View this image ›
